feed.title: NewsTracker: ebola
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Liberia investigates how latest Ebola patient got infected
entry.summary:
The West African nation has seen the most deaths in the Ebola outbreak, with more than 4,200 of the more than 10,000 dead across the region.

In a worrying sign, she doesn't seem to be linked to any of the people on an Ebola contacts list and says she has not traveled recently to the neighboring infected countries of Sierra Leone and Guinea.

entry.title: Liberia reports first Ebola infection in a month
entry.summary:
"A woman has been confirmed as an Ebola patient... This is a new case after we have gone more than 27 days without a single case. It is a setback," government spokesman Lewis Brown told AFP.

Surveillance and early warning systems detected 125 suspected cases in the week to March 15 but none tested positive for Ebola.

entry.title: Liberia officials: New patient tests positive for Ebola
entry.summary:
But since it discharged its last case on March 5, it was counting down the 42 days countries must wait before being declared Ebola-free.

Now, a new patient has tested positive, said Dr. Francis Kateh, the acting head of the country's Ebola Incident Management Team.

Tolbert Nyenswah, who runs Liberia's Ebola response, also said he had been told the test result was positive.

Although hopes were high that Liberia had beaten Ebola, officials knew that until two neighboring countries - Sierra Leone and Guinea - also beat the disease, Liberia would remain at risk.

entry.title: Liberia reports first Ebola case in weeks
entry.summary:
Liberian Information Minister Lewis Brown said that a 44-year-old woman had been transferred to the ELWA Ebola treatment unit in the capital Monrovia after testing positive for the virus.

In Liberia, the government had hoped to declare the country Ebola-free next month, 42 days after the last patient tested negative for a second time, which would mark double the length of the virus's incubation period.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary:
When aid agency Doctors Without Borders warned Ebola was spiraling out of control, WHO contradicted it, even as WHO's own scientists called for backup.

As Ebola continued to spread in the summer, the situation on the ground grew increasingly desperate, with only a fraction of the needed treatment beds available in Liberia and Sierra Leone.

It was around that time that West Africa's Ebola epidemic surpassed the previous largest outbreak, in Uganda, where it infected 425 people in 2000 and killed about half.

Guinean officials' insistence on only reporting confirmed cases was intended to "minimize artificially the magnitude of the Ebola outbreak to reassure expatriates working in the mining industry," Formenty, the WHO Ebola expert, wrote in another trip report.

On June 4, scientist Lucien Manga wrote to Briand to tell her senior staff in Africa had proposed declaring the Ebola outbreak a global emergency.

Infectious diseases expert Osterholm said the global health agency isn't the only one to be blamed and that the entire world failed to respond quickly enough to stop Ebola from becoming a humanitarian disaster.

entry.title: Liberia reports new case of Ebola
entry.summary: She doesn't seem to be linked to any of the people on a list of contacts of other Ebola patients, he added.

entry.title: Hunting for the next Ebola outbreak in the deep African jungle
entry.summary:
Kenneth Cameron, a compact, energetic man who works for the New York-based Wildlife Conservation Society, had spent much of his life quietly pursuing Ebola through Central Africa.

In West Africa, the recent Ebola outbreak probably began with a two-year-old Guinean boy who touched a droplet of bat faeces in December 2013.

entry.title: Spike in Ebola in Guinea could reflect access to hidden patients
Why WHO waited on Ebola: E-mails reveal politics behind slow response
entry.summary: By early June of last year, the Ebola epidemic in West Africa was the deadliest ever recorded.

entry.title: Claims UN resisted Ebola declaration
entry.summary:
In mid-April, an experienced Ebola expert with WHO's Africa office wrote to Geneva, with disturbing news many staffers at a leading hospital in Guinea had been exposed to the virus.

WHO's Ebola response leader, Dr Bruce Aylward, couldn't say whether an earlier declaration would have made a difference, noting that "the overall response slowed down" after the emergency was declared.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary:
Britain, China, the U.S. and others all built Ebola clinics in West Africa, but many weren't ready until late fall - after the epidemic's peak.

By the end of August, the biggest Ebola hospital run by Doctors Without Borders in the Liberian capital could only open for 30 minutes every morning and people were dying on the ground outside the gates.

entry.title: UN ignored Ebola warnings and RESISTED declaring public emergency, secret emails reveal
entry.summary: Britain and France also pledged to build Ebola clinics, while China sent a 59-person lab team and Cuba sent more than 400 health workers.

entry.title: Emails show UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary:
Fellow responders said many lacked Ebola experience; one WHO consultant who got infected with Ebola broke his own agency's protocol, putting others at risk and getting WHO kicked out of a hotel, the AP found.

In an email Thursday, WHO said: "People often confuse the declaration of a Public Health Emergency of International Concern with our operational response. It is very different. WHO mounted a strong operational response a year ago when we were notified the outbreak was Ebola."

entry.title: 5 key findings from AP's story on WHO and the Ebola outbreak
entry.summary:
4, 2014 file photo, people watch as a health worker, right, sprays a man suspected of dying from Ebola with disinfectant chemicals in Monrovia, Liberia.

Internal emails and documents suggest the U.N. health agency was afraid of provoking conflict with the Ebola-stricken countries and wary that a declaration could interfere with the economy and the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca.

An Ebola-infected WHO consultant in Sierra Leone violated WHO health protocols, creating a rift with Doctors Without Borders that was only resolved when WHO was thrown out of a shared hotel.

entry.title: Emails show UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency on economic, political grounds
entry.summary: But Dr. Bruce Aylward, WHO's top Ebola official, said labeling the Ebola outbreak a global emergency would have been no magic bullet.

entry.title: Emails show UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency on economic, political grounds
Ebola outbreak: Sierra Leone to lock down hotspots next week
entry.summary:
The number of Ebola cases in the region has fallen in recent months, though a spike in Guinea highlights the risk of complacency, over a year into the worst outbreak on record.

The rains are due to begin in May. The World Health Organization has said they could greatly complicate the fight against Ebola by washing away roads and making it harder for aid and health-care workers to get to affected areas.

The latest figures issued by the WHO showed that there had been 10,216 confirmed, probable and suspected deaths from Ebola in West Africa.

Guinea, where the outbreak was first identified, has recorded 2,231 confirmed and probable deaths from Ebola but has seen a recent spike, with the number of patients more than doubling since last month.

entry.title: Healthcare worker in Nebraska tests negative for Ebola
entry.summary: The individual has returned to a housing facility near the medical center where the four other individuals are being monitored for the remainder of the 21-day Ebola incubation period.

entry.title: Ebola: Sierra Leone plans second lockdown to stem epidemic
entry.summary:
The action, which follows a nationwide lockdown in September, was announced after the World Health Organisation (WHO) said on Wednesday that the death toll from Ebola stood at almost 10,200.

Authorities hope the lockdown will set the country back on course to meet a mid-April deadline for eradicating Ebola, as announced by the leaders of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone in February.

The country reported 55 new confirmed cases, the lowest weekly total since late June 2014, and WHO chief Margaret Chan said on Wednesday it had made "tremendous progress" in combating Ebola.

entry.title: Guinea says number of Ebola patients more than doubles since Feb
entry.summary:
But there is still resistance to the anti-Ebola effort in Guinea, which is struggling to control the outbreak and has overtaken Sierra Leone as the main hub for transmission.

Dr Rafiou Diallo, a spokesman for Guinea's health ministry, said there were 91 suspected and confirmed Ebola patients in treatment centres compared with just 39 in February.

The number of Ebola cases in Guinea peaked in late December when there were nearly double current number of patients at 171, according to the World Health Organisation.

The current Ebola outbreak was first confirmed in Guinea's remote southeastern forest region last March.

Unlike Liberia and Sierra Leone, the other two worst hit nations where U.S. and British military forces deployed to support the fight against Ebola, Guinea has not seen a large scale foreign military intervention.

entry.title: Liberia: Families of health workers killed by Ebola get $5k
Two more U.S. healthcare workers repatriated for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: Neither of the two healthcare workers brought back Wednesday has tested positive for Ebola, but they are being monitored because they might have been exposed to a colleague who has contracted it.

entry.title: 2 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: All are connected to an unidentified American who returned to the U.S. last week after he came down with Ebola.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another three-day, countrywide shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: The shutdown is expected to take place March 27 through 29, according to Patrick Fatoma, another official with the Ebola response center.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary:
In the drive to zero cases in Sierra Leone, the government will again ask residents to stay in their homes for three days, Alfred Palo Conteh, head of the country's National Ebola Response Center, said Wednesday.

Sierra Leone is "hoping it will be the last push to end Ebola outbreak. We want it to be community-owned and for people to do the proper things," said Fatoma.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: The West Africa Ebola outbreak that has killed more than 10,000 people is declining but the disease has remained stubbornly entrenched in parts of Guinea and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: FDA panel to discuss Ebola vaccine development in May
entry.summary: Mapp Biopharmaceutical's ZMapp and a compound from Tekmira Pharmaceuticals Corp have so far shown they could cure non-human primates given injections of Ebola virus.

entry.title: Guinea Ebola cases rise; three doctors infected
entry.summary:
Ending Ebola could reboot Guinea's mining-dependent economy that has been hammered by the outbreak, which has scared investors, he said.

A big source of concern is a chain of new infections that can be linked back to a woman who died of Ebola and was not buried safely, according to Fatoumata Lejeune-Kaba, spokeswoman for the U.N.'s Ebola emergency response mission UNMEER.

entry.title: Guinea sees 'major setback' as new Ebola cases spike
entry.summary:
Guinea has suffered a setback in its fight against Ebola with a rash of new cases, including three doctors infected by the virus, with officials blaming weak surveillance and a failure to follow safety procedures.

Guinea officials said the new cases came from high risk Ebola contacts who had left Forecariah and developed symptoms elsewhere, pointing to poor surveillance.

entry.title: Guinea Ebola cases rise, three doctors infected
entry.summary:
Sakoba Keita, Guinea's anti-Ebola task force coordinator, said on Tuesday that the government was putting in place new measures including strict rules regulating the movement of corpses and contact tracing.

"There are numerous gaps in the Ebola response in Guinea, notably in surveillance of contacts, and that explains the difficulty in making any lasting progress towards ending the epidemic," said a spokesman for medical charity MSF.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: On Tuesday, March 17, 2015, health officials said four more medical aid workers have been flown from West Africa to the United States, for monitoring for Ebola.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: But medical superintendent Dr. Peter George said the hospital hasn't had any Ebola cases for quite some time.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary:
The Ebola virus is spread through contact with a sick patient's blood or bodily fluids.

Since last summer, several U.S. aid workers have gotten Ebola and have been flown back to the U.S. for care.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary:
None of them have been diagnosed with Ebola, but they will be isolated and monitored during the next three weeks for signs of the disease.

But all 16 are connected to -- or had direct physical contact with -- another American who came down with Ebola last week in Africa.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
U.S. Ebola patient now in critical condition: NIH
entry.summary: The healthcare workers will voluntarily isolate themselves during the remainder of the 21-day Ebola incubation period, Partners in Health said.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola now in critical condition
entry.summary: One of those being monitored in Nebraska has developed symptoms of Ebola and was being moved to an isolation unit, hospital officials said in a news release Monday.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola now in critical condition
entry.summary: The latest NIH patient is the 11th person with Ebola to be treated in the U.S. Two patients in the U.S. have died: a man treated in Dallas after contracting the virus in Africa and a doctor evacuated from Africa to Nebraska when he was already critically ill.

entry.title: Four Americans arrive in Nebraska to be monitored for Ebola virus
entry.summary: The individuals arrived on Saturday and are being housed on the University of Nebraska Medical Center campus in Omaha, where medical personnel will monitor them for 21 days for any Ebola symptoms, hospital spokesman Taylor Wilson said.

entry.title: 10 Americans evacuated from Sierra Leone to be monitored for Ebola
entry.summary: Ten health care workers with a Boston-based nonprofit organization responding to Sierra Leone's Ebola outbreak are to be evacuated to the United States after one of their colleagues was infected with the deadly disease.

entry.title: 10 US charity staff to leave Sierra Leone amid Ebola scare
entry.summary:
None of them were sick, but if they do develop Ebola they will be treated in the hospital's specialized biocontainment unit.

On March 11, a Partners in Health medical worker in Sierra Leone tested positive for Ebola, and the 10 fellow workers "came to the aid of their ailing colleague," the organization's statement said.

entry.title: 10 US charity staff to leave Sierra Leone amid Ebola scare
entry.summary:
Partners in Health said in a statement Saturday that the 10, the largest group to be evacuated to the United States over possible Ebola exposure, would travel on non-commercial aircraft and be isolated in Ebola treatment facilities.

The 10 have not shown signs of Ebola and Partners in Health said the evacuations were ordered "out of an abundance of caution."

"They will remain in isolation near designated U.S. Ebola treatment facilities to ensure access to rapid testing and treatment in the unlikely instance that any become symptomatic," the group's statement said.

In both countries there are still regular attacks against Western aid workers and officials are unable to track where the Ebola virus is spreading.

entry.title: Americans evacuated after possible Ebola contact
entry.summary:
The World Health Organisation says its tally of Ebola deaths has passed 10,000, mostly in West Africa.

Another aid worker, who was showing signs of illness, arrived in the US on Friday evening, hours after a colleague with Ebola was flown from Sierra Leone to the clinical centre of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland.

The workers served at an Ebola treatment unit run by the US charity Partners in Health in the Port Loko district in northern Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Americans returning from Africa for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: Earlier this week, an American health care worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in Sierra Leone was brought to the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland, for treatment.

entry.title: Ebola: at least 10 US citizens possibly exposed to be flown back from Africa
entry.summary:
CDC spokesman Thomas Skinner said 10 people who may have been exposed to the unidentified Ebola patient or who had a similar exposure to the virus as the patient were being flown to the US.

If an individual shows symptoms, they will be transported to an Ebola treatment center for evaluation and care, the CDC said.

entry.title: U.S. healthcare worker with Ebola in 'serious' condition, NIH says
entry.summary:
The National Institutes of Health said the U.S. Ebola patient was flown into the United States earlier on Friday and admitted to the NIH's high-security containment facility in Maryland.

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said another American volunteering in Sierra Leone had "potential exposure" to that patient and was being transported to the Atlanta area to be near Emory University Hospital, which has treated other Ebola patients.

The developments followed a relatively quiet period for Ebola in the United States, a reminder that while the spread of the virus has eased somewhat in West Africa, it still remains dangerous.

The CDC said that as a result of the latest case it is working to trace the contacts of volunteers combating Ebola in Sierra Leone, including several other Americans, who may have been exposed to the healthcare worker now at the NIH.

A British healthcare worker who tested positive for Ebola while in Sierra Leone was flown back this week to Britain, along with four others who are being monitored for possible infection.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone arrives at Maryland hospital
entry.summary: The center's Special Clinical Studies Unit is staffed by specialists in infectious disease and critical care and is designed to prevent the spread of highly contagious viruses, including Ebola.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola in Africa arrives at hospital in Maryland for treatment
entry.summary:
The patient is the 11th person with Ebola to be treated in the U.S. and the second admitted to the NIH Clinical Center.

Like Emory, NIH has one of the few specialized isolation units nationwide set up to treat Ebola patients.

None of the volunteers in Sierra Leone who had contact with the NIH patient have tested positive for Ebola.

entry.title: News24.com | American with Ebola to be treated in US
entry.summary: Previously, an American nurse was treated there after she contracted Ebola while caring for a Liberian man who died at a Dallas hospital.

entry.title: NBC News' Nancy Snyderman resigns following Ebola quarantine scandal
entry.summary: While she continued working after that, she never did another Ebola story for NBC News.

entry.title: Nancy Snyderman leaves NBC after Ebola controversy
entry.summary: "Covering the Ebola epidemic last fall in Liberia, and then becoming part of the story upon my return to the U.S., contributed to my decision that now is the time to return to academic medicine.

entry.title: Liberia's last Ebola patient leaves treatment center
entry.summary: Resistance to Ebola containment efforts also continues to be a problem in Guinea and Sierra Leone, which have both reported numerous "security incidents" or other forms of refusal to cooperate.

entry.title: Last Ebola patient is released in Liberia
entry.summary: The St. Paul's Bridge community where she resides and teaches had become the last "hotspot" for Ebola cases in Monrovia, according to Tolbert Nyenswah, Assistant Health Minister and head of the country's Ebola response.

entry.title: Last Ebola patient is released in Liberia
entry.summary:
Liberia released its last Ebola patient, a 58-year old English teacher, from a treatment center in the capital on Thursday, beginning its countdown to being declared Ebola free.

Ebola patient Beatrice Yardolo, center, leaves the Chinese Ebola treatment center were she was treated, surrounded by Ebola health workers on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia, Thursday, March 5, 2015.

Yardolo said she had been admitted to the Chinese-run Ebola treatment center in the Paynesville district of Monrovia on Feb. 18.

entry.title: Liberia begins countdown to Ebola-free status as final patient released
entry.summary:
He challenged all Liberians to commit themselves to achieving "zero Ebola infections" by rigidly abiding by the anti-Ebola regulations.

Liberian President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has said no country can be declared Ebola-free until all the other countries have no cases.

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary:
The World Health Organization says it will soon start large-scale testing of an experimental Ebola vaccine in Guinea to see how effective it might be in preventing future outbreaks of the dreaded virus.

In a statement issued on Thursday, March 5, 2015, the U.N. health agency said the study will be focused in Basse Guinee, the region that currently has the most Ebola cases in the country.

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary:
The health agency's vaccination strategy in Guinea aims to create a buffer zone around an Ebola case to prevent its further spread - an approach used to eradicate smallpox in the 1970s.

WHO also said unsafe traditional burials - a high-risk factor for Ebola transmission - continue to occur in both Guinea and Sierra Leone, and health workers in those countries are still being attacked by those wary of their efforts.

Officials also said the number of Ebola deaths taking place outside of hospitals still remains high in Guinea and Sierra Leone, "suggesting that the need for early isolation and treatment is not yet understood, accepted or acted upon."

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary:
The West African nations of Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been hardest hit in the yearlong Ebola outbreak, which is estimated to have left more than 9,800 people dead.

In a statement Thursday, the U.N. health agency said the vaccine study will focus on Basse Guinee, the region that has Guinea's most Ebola cases.

The agency said the spread of Ebola remains "widespread" in Sierra Leone and noted that cases have jumped both there and in Guinea.

entry.title: Liberia releases last Ebola patient
entry.summary: There are no other confirmed cases of Ebola in the country, and as such Liberia can begin to count up to 42 days to be declared Ebola free in keeping with World Health Organization protocols and standards, Nyenswah said Wednesday.

entry.title: North Korea opens marathon to foreigners after Ebola ban lifted
entry.summary:
TOKYO - After lifting travel restrictions it imposed because of concerns over the Ebola virus, North Korea says foreigners can now take part in one of its most popular tourist events - the annual Pyongyang marathon, a travel agency said Thursday.

Even though no cases of Ebola have been reported anywhere near North Korea, the country shut out foreign tourists in October with some of the strictest Ebola regulations in the world, including saying that only local runners would be allowed into the marathon in April.

entry.title: West African leaders urge Ebola 'Marshall Plan'
entry.summary:
The countries at the center of the Ebola epidemic are forecast to lose 12 percent of their combined gross domestic product this year, according to World Bank estimates.

In addition, their health sectors have been partially wiped out by the epidemic, or forced to divert resources to fighting Ebola at the expense of other diseases like measles, malaria and AIDS.

Countries around the world have so far pledged $5.1 billion to fight Ebola, with $2.4 billion disbursed until now, according to the statement.

entry.title: Liberia's leader calls for 'Marshall Plan' to eradicate Ebola, rebuild economies
entry.summary:
Sirleaf told fellow regional leaders and delegates at an international conference on Ebola in Brussels that restoring economic growth in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone is a long-term and costly task.

Even if the number of new Ebola cases in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone has dropped markedly, bringing it down to zero will still take a significant effort.

entry.title: Ohio bridal shop linked to Ebola survivor is selling building after business suffered
entry.summary: Dallas nurse Amber Vinson visited Coming Attractions Bridal & Formal in Akron days before she was diagnosed with Ebola last fall.

entry.title: Report: As Ebola wanes, other countries remain vulnerable
entry.summary:
Some of the travelers checked by workers with surgical masks had traveled through a West African country affected by Ebola, or sat next to passengers who did, and Chadian authorities weren't taking any chances.

Impoverished countries like Chad know the only way to stay Ebola-free is to keep any infected people out.

The report said only Somalia is worse prepared than Chad for an epidemic such as Ebola.

After causing nearly 10,000 recorded deaths, the Ebola epidemic is waning in the three worst-hit countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

It found that 28 countries were worse off than Liberia, which has seen the most deaths from the Ebola epidemic that began in December 2013.

entry.title: North Korea lifts Ebola travel restrictions
entry.summary:
"We have been informed by Air Koryo that North Korea's borders are now open for travel and the four-month long Ebola travel ban was lifted as of Monday," Uri Tours said.

Officials in Pyongyang said the restrictions and quarantines would continue for visitors from Ebola-affected countries in Africa and those countries that have borders with them.

North Korean media had suggested the Ebola virus was created by the U.S. military for use as a biological weapon.

entry.title: US aid worker who survived Ebola heads back to Liberia after her recovery from deadly illness
entry.summary: Nancy Writebol last summer became the second American infected with the Ebola virus while working at a hospital SIM supports in the Liberian capital of Monrovia.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary:
Duncan, who contracted Ebola in his native Liberia but started showing symptoms during a trip to the U.S., died at the hospital.

On the first day Pham treated Duncan, when Ebola was suspected but not yet diagnosed, she wore a regular isolation gown, double gloves, a surgical mask with a plastic shield and double booties.

Pham says that after Duncan died, she was told that what she had worn was safe and that she had no risk of contracting Ebola.

She says he falsely claimed that the hospital was trained to manage Ebola and that he misrepresented the type of protective equipment that nurses wore while caring for Duncan.

Varga testified that as the Ebola epidemic worsened over the summer, the hospital system began educating doctors, nurses and other staff on symptoms and risk factors.

entry.title: UN warns against complacency as Ebola fight enters tough new phase
entry.summary: But U.N. Special Envoy on Ebola David Nabarro said the fight has reached a "second phase, getting to zero, and it really is the hardest part."

entry.title: UN warns against complacency as Ebola fight enters new phase
entry.summary: "It's a really difficult, painstaking task," he said in Brussels, on the eve of a major international conference on Ebola expected to draw around 600 delegates, including the leaders of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Nurse who was first person infected with Ebola in U.S. sues Dallas hospital
entry.summary: The first person infected with Ebola in the United States, nurse Nina Pham, sued a Texas hospital on Monday, saying it did not do enough to prevent her from contracting the deadly virus and invaded her privacy after she was diagnosed with it.

entry.title: Ebola survivor sues Dallas hospital over infection
entry.summary:
Pham became a national symbol of hope in fighting Ebola after she made a recovery and was greeted in the Oval Office by President Barack Obama.

The suit claims that the THR's Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital did not initially provide adequate protective gear for medical staff or instructions on how to treat someone with Ebola.

"I was hoping that THR would be more open and honest about everything that happened at the hospital, and the things they didn't do that led to me getting infected with Ebola. But that didn't happen and I felt I was left with no choice but to turn to the courts for help," Pham said in a statement.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: Pham says in her lawsuit that the hospital was unprepared to treat Ebola cases and that she was an unwitting pawn in its public relations campaign to restore its reputation.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
?Used as a PR pawn?: Nurse who survived Ebola infection says Texas hospital failed her
entry.summary:
She also told the newspaper that Texas Health Resources was negligent because it failed to develop policies and train its staff for treating Ebola patients.

Pham and another nurse who worked at Texas Health Presbyterian, Amber Vinson, both became infected with Ebola after caring for Duncan, according to medical records released to The Associated Press.

entry.title: Nurse Treated For Ebola To Sue Texas Hospital
First Ebola-infected U.S. nurse plans to sue, says hospital didn't train her properly
entry.summary:
Pham, 26, told the newspaper that chaos hit the Dallas hospital when it admitted Thomas Duncan, the first person diagnosed with Ebola in the United States after he contracted it in Liberia.

Nurses were ill prepared and received little guidance on how to treat Ebola or protect themselves.

Another nurse who treated Duncan, Amber Vinson, also became infected with Ebola and recovered.

entry.title: Sierra Leone's Samuel Sam-Sumana in quarantine over Ebola worries
entry.summary:
Despite his quarantine, Sam-Sumana is set to become acting president later Sunday when President Ernest Bai Koroma leaves Sierra Leone to attend a EU conference on Ebola in Belgium.

Sam-Sumana voluntarily decided to quarantine himself for 21 days following the death from Ebola last Tuesday of one of his security personnel, according to the Sierra Leone Broadcasting Corporation.

Sam-Sumana's dramatic quarantine comes as Sierra Leone is experiencing a rise in new Ebola cases which prompted President Ernest Bai Koroma to reinstate restrictions on Saturday.

Sierra Leone recorded 18 new cases of Ebola in the week ending Saturday, up from 16 new cases last week.

entry.title: Liberia lifts Ebola curfew and re-opens borders
WHO official concerned as decline in Ebola cases levels off
entry.summary: The United Nations has said 10 times fewer people are being diagnosed with Ebola each week than in September.

entry.title: WHO: Sharp Decline in Ebola Cases Has Now Leveled Off
Obama to discuss Ebola response with Liberia's president
entry.summary: In a statement, the White House says Obama and Sirleaf will discuss the current Ebola response and the region's economic recovery plans during their Feb. 27 meeting.

entry.title: World Health Organization approves 1st quick test for Ebola
entry.summary:
Until now, Ebola tests have been mainly conducted in laboratories.

The new test can provide results within 15 minutes by detecting an Ebola protein.

Almost 24,000 people have been infected and nearly 9,400 people have died from the current Ebola outbreak, which began in West Africa over a year ago.

entry.title: Health24.com | Breakthrough 15-minute Ebola test gets the nod
entry.summary:
The World Health Organisation has approved the first rapid test for Ebola, it said on Friday.

The health charity Medecins Sans Frontieres, which has been at the forefront of the fight against Ebola, had expressed an interest, he said.

It is able to correctly identify about 92 percent of Ebola infected patients and 85 percent of those not infected with the virus, the WHO said.

"The big fear has been that the market gets flooded with tests of unknown quality, or unknown performance, and with Ebola you need to know what are the limitations. A false positive has enormous implications. So does a false positive," she said.

"If you had five patients with suspected symptoms and you went ahead and tested them and they were all positive you'd have a high degree of confidence that you've got Ebola."

entry.title: WHO approves 15-minute Ebola test
Fifteen-minute Ebola test approved
entry.summary: Trials in West Africa suggest it correctly identifies about 92% of people who have Ebola.

entry.title: Liberia leader to visit US, 1st visit since Ebola outbreak
entry.summary: Since an Ebola outbreak began in December 2013 in the West African country of Guinea, there have been about 7,900 deaths, mostly in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
entry.summary:
Monrovia: Thousands of Liberian children in pristine uniforms flocked back to school for the first time in six months, after a after a closure designed to stem the spread of the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

At the peak, last summer, Ebola patients were collapsing outside overflowing hospitals.

"Authorities in the three countries are looking at catchup sessions and cancelling some school vacations. It will be challenging," said Sayo Aoki, education specialist in Ebola Emergencies at the UN Children's Fund.

entry.title: Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
entry.summary:
"Government wishes to make it abundantly clear that those who are found guilty of misusing Ebola funds will face the full force of the law," it said.

The report by Sierra Leone's Auditor General covered the months of May through October 2014, and looked at donations received directly by the government to fight Ebola.

More than 3,300 people have died from Ebola with nearly 11,000 cases over the past year in Sierra Leone, where transmission remains the highest in the world.

As Ebola is being brought under control, Sierra Leone plans to re-open its schools at the end of March.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary:
Liberia has seen the highest death toll from the Ebola epidemic, with 3,800 killed.

In Sierra Leone on Monday, the government promised a full investigation after an internal audit found that nearly one-third of the money it received to fight Ebola was used without saving the necessary receipts and invoices to justify the spending.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary: Nearly 9,200 people have died since the first Ebola deaths in rural Guinea in December 2013.

entry.title: Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
Sierra Leone fishing district quarantined with new Ebola cases
entry.summary: Sierra Leone has seen nearly 11,000 confirmed, probable and suspected Ebola cases during the worst Ebola outbreak in history, the most of any country, according to the World Health Organization.

entry.title: Ebola cases prompt mini-quarantine in Sierra Leone capital
